Foundation of Islam
objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes.
description: The year 622 marks the Hijra, when the Prophet Muhammad migrated from Mecca to Medina, marking the beginning of the Islamic calendar and the spread of Islam.

title: The First Crusade
objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes.
description: The First Crusade began in 1096, as European Christians sought to reclaim Jerusalem and other holy lands from Muslim control, impacting Christian-Muslim relations.

title: The Magna Carta
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique.
description: In 1215, King John of England was forced to sign the Magna Carta, which limited the power of the monarchy and laid the foundation for modern democracy.

title: Foundation of Islam

description: In 622, the Prophet Muhammad's migration from Mecca to Medina, known as the Hijra, marks the beginning of the Islamic calendar and the establishment of the first Muslim community.

title: Council of Nicaea
objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes
description: The Council of Nicaea in 325 AD was the first ecumenical council of the Christian Church, leading to the Nicene Creed and establishing foundational Christian doctrine.

title: The Great Schism
objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes
description: In 1054, the Christian Church split into the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church, a division known as the Great Schism, which shaped the religious landscape of Europe.

title: Signing of the Magna Carta
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique
description: In 1215, King John of England signed the Magna Carta, limiting royal power and laying the foundation for modern constitutional governance.

title: Battle of Hastings
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique
description: The Battle of Hastings in 1066 resulted in Norman control of England, significantly altering the social and political structure of medieval England.

title: Creation of the Holy Roman Empire
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique
description: In 962, Otto I was crowned Holy Roman Emperor, which established a central European empire influencing medieval politics and society.

title: Columbus Discovers America
theme: Regards sur l’Europe et le monde XVIe–XVIIe
objective: Comprendre les grandes découvertes, réformes religieuses et colonisations
description: In 1492, Christopher Columbus's voyage across the Atlantic Ocean led to the European discovery of the Americas, initiating widespread exploration and colonization.

objective: Comprendre les grandes découvertes, réformes religieuses et colonisations
description: In 1517, Martin Luther's publication of the 95 Theses challenged the practices of the Catholic Church, sparking the Protestant Reformation and religious change across Europe.

title: Treaty of Tordesillas

objective: Comprendre les grandes découvertes, réformes religieuses et colonisations
description: The Treaty of Tordesillas in 1494 divided the newly discovered lands outside Europe between the Portuguese Empire and the Spanish Empire, influencing global colonization.

objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes
description: The year 622 marks the Hijra, when Prophet Muhammad migrated from Mecca to Medina, an event that signifies the foundation of the Islamic community.

title: Council of Nicaea
objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes
description: The First Council of Nicaea was a gathering of Christian bishops convened to achieve consensus in the church through an assembly representing all of Christendom.

title: The Great Schism
objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes
description: The Great Schism was the break of communion between the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church, marking a significant division in Christianity.

title: The Treaty of Verdun
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique
description: The Treaty of Verdun divided the Carolingian Empire into three kingdoms, laying the foundations for the modern states of Europe.

title: The Investiture Controversy
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique
description: A significant conflict between church and state in medieval Europe over the ability to appoint local church officials.

title: Signing of the Magna Carta
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique
description: The Magna Carta was a charter agreed by King John of England that granted certain rights and laid the foundation for modern democracy.

description: Christopher Columbus's voyage led to the discovery of the Americas by Europeans, marking the beginning of widespread European exploration and colonization.

objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes.

title: Couronnement de Charlemagne
objective: Comprendre l’organisation de la société et l’évolution du pouvoir politique.
description: Charlemagne est couronné empereur à Rome, renforçant l'idée d'une Europe chrétienne unifiée sous un pouvoir central.

title: Première croisade
objective: Comprendre la naissance et la diffusion des religions monothéistes.
description: La première croisade est lancée pour reprendre Jérusalem aux musulmans, illustrant les tensions religieuses et les interactions entre chrétienté et Islam.

theme: Regards sur l’Europe et le monde XVIe–XVIIe
objective: Comprendre les grandes découvertes, réformes religieuses et colonisations.
description: Christophe Colomb atteint les Amériques, ouvrant une ère de colonisation et d'échanges entre l'Europe et le Nouveau Monde.

Henry VIII Establishes the Church of England
objective: Study the Renaissance and Reformation in Europe and their effects on Britain.
description: In 1534, King Henry VIII broke away from the Roman Catholic Church and established the Church of England. This was a significant event in the Reformation, as it led to religious reforms and conflicts in Britain. It marked the beginning of a series of religious transformations and political power shifts.

title: Act of Supremacy
objective: Examine the causes and consequences of the English Reformation.
description: The Act of Supremacy was passed by the English Parliament, declaring King Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England. This marked a significant shift in religious power from the Pope to the English monarchy, leading to the establishment of the Church of England and the beginning of the English Reformation.

title: The English Civil War Begins
objective: Analyze the causes and events of the civil wars throughout Britain.
description: The English Civil War began in 1642 as a conflict between King Charles I and Parliament. The war was primarily over issues of governance and the power of the monarchy versus Parliament. It led to years of conflict and significant changes in the political landscape of England.

title: The Invention of the Spinning Jenny
objective: Understand Britain as the first industrial nation and its impact on society.
description: The Spinning Jenny, invented by James Hargreaves, revolutionized the textile industry by allowing a single worker to spin multiple spools of thread at once, significantly increasing productivity and contributing to Britain's emergence as the first industrial nation.

title: The Battle of Plassey
objective: Study the development of the British Empire and its global impact.
description: The Battle of Plassey was a decisive victory of the British East India Company over the Nawab of Bengal and his French allies. This victory marked the beginning of British rule in India, significantly expanding the British Empire's influence in Asia.

title: Dunkirk Evacuation
objective: Study the events and impact of World War II, including the leadership of Winston Churchill.
description: The evacuation of Allied soldiers from the beaches and harbor of Dunkirk, France, between May 26 and June 4, 1940. It was a significant event during World War II and showcased the leadership of Winston Churchill as he coordinated the rescue of over 330,000 troops.

title: Kristallnacht (The Night of Broken Glass)
objective: Understand the events and significance of the Holocaust.
description: A pogrom against Jews carried out by SA paramilitary forces and civilians throughout Nazi Germany. Jewish homes, schools, and businesses were vandalized, and synagogues were set on fire. This event marked a significant escalation in the Nazi regime's anti-Jewish policies and led to the further marginalization and persecution of Jews.

title: Indian Independence Act
objective: Examine the process and impact of Indian independence and the end of the British Empire.
description: The Indian Independence Act of 1947 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom that partitioned British India into two new independent dominions of India and Pakistan. The Act received royal assent on 18 July 1947, and India and Pakistan came into being on 15 August 1947. This marked the end of British rule in India and led to the creation of two sovereign states.

title: Representation of the People Act
objective: Study the movement for women's suffrage and its achievements.
description: The Representation of the People Act 1918 granted the right to vote to women over the age of 30 who met certain property qualifications. This was a significant milestone in the women's suffrage movement in the United Kingdom, marking the first time women were allowed to vote in general elections.

title: The First Crusade Launched
objective: Explore the significance of the Crusades in Medieval history.
description: The First Crusade was initiated in 1096 following Pope Urban II's call to help the Byzantine Empire and reclaim Jerusalem from Muslim control. This marked the beginning of a series of religious wars in the Middle Ages aimed at recovering the Holy Land, significantly impacting European and Middle Eastern history.

title: The Black Death Reaches England
objective: Analyze the social and economic impact of the Black Death.
description: In 1348, the Black Death, a devastating pandemic, arrived in England. Carried by fleas on rats, it spread rapidly, killing approximately one-third of the population. This catastrophic event led to severe labor shortages, which empowered surviving workers to demand higher wages, ultimately weakening the feudal system and prompting significant social and economic changes.

title: Martin Luther's 95 Theses
objective: Explore the cultural and religious changes during the Renaissance and Reformation.
description: Martin Luther, a German monk, nailed his 95 Theses to the door of the Wittenberg Castle Church, challenging the practices of the Catholic Church and sparking the Protestant Reformation.

title: Henry VIII's Act of Supremacy
objective: Examine the religious transformations in England from Henry VIII to Mary I.
description: The Act of Supremacy was passed, declaring Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England, marking a significant break from the Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Glorious Revolution
objective: Understand the political changes during the Glorious Revolution.
description: The Glorious Revolution occurred when William of Orange invaded England, leading to the overthrow of King James II. This event marked a significant shift in the balance of power between the monarchy and Parliament, leading to the establishment of a constitutional monarchy.

title: Invention of the Spinning Jenny
objective: Analyze the impact of Britain as the first industrial nation.
description: The Spinning Jenny was invented by James Hargreaves in 1764. This invention revolutionized the textile industry by allowing a single worker to spin multiple spools of thread at the same time, greatly increasing productivity and contributing to the rapid industrialization of Britain.

title: The Battle of Plassey
objective: Study the development and impact of the British Empire.
description: The Battle of Plassey was a decisive victory of the British East India Company over the Nawab of Bengal and his French allies, marking the beginning of British control in India. This battle laid the foundation for the British Empire in India, leading to extensive British influence and eventual direct control over the Indian subcontinent.

title: D-Day Invasion
objective: Understand the global impact and leadership during World War Two.
description: The D-Day invasion, also known as Operation Overlord, took place on June 6, 1944. It was a massive Allied operation involving American, British, and Canadian forces landing on the beaches of Normandy, France. This event marked a significant turning point in World War Two as it led to the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi control.

title: Kristallnacht (The Night of Broken Glass)
objective: Study the events and significance of the Holocaust.
description: A pogrom against Jews carried out by SA paramilitary forces and civilians throughout Nazi Germany on 9–10 November 1938. The name Kristallnacht ('Crystal Night') refers to the shards of broken glass that littered the streets after the windows of Jewish-owned stores, buildings, and synagogues were smashed. This event marked a significant escalation in the Nazi regime's persecution of Jews, leading to the Holocaust.

title: Indian Independence Act
objective: Examine the process and impact of Indian independence.
description: This act, passed by the British Parliament, led to the partition of British India into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan. It marked the end of British rule in India and was a crucial event in the process of Indian independence.

title: The Black Death Reaches England
objective: Analyze the social and economic impact of the Black Death in Medieval Europe.
description: The Black Death, one of the deadliest pandemics in human history, arrived in England in 1348. It led to the death of a significant portion of the population, causing profound social and economic changes. The drastic reduction in the workforce led to increased wages for peasants and a shift in power dynamics between the lower classes and the nobility, as labor became more valuable. This event marked a turning point in medieval society, leading to long-term changes in the structure of European economies and societies.

title: Battle of Bosworth Field
objective: Investigate the causes and outcomes of the Wars of the Roses.
description: The Battle of Bosworth Field was the last significant battle of the Wars of the Roses. It marked the defeat of King Richard III by the forces of Henry Tudor, who became King Henry VII, effectively ending the conflict and beginning the Tudor dynasty.

title: The Act of Supremacy
objective: Study the causes and effects of the English Reformation.
description: The Act of Supremacy was passed by the English Parliament, declaring King Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England. This marked a significant break from the Roman Catholic Church and was a crucial event in the English Reformation.

title: The Glorious Revolution
objective: Explore the events and significance of the Glorious Revolution.
description: The Glorious Revolution of 1688 was a pivotal event in British history where King James II was overthrown and replaced by William of Orange and his wife Mary. This bloodless revolution led to the establishment of a constitutional monarchy in England, limiting the powers of the monarchy and laying the foundation for modern parliamentary democracy.

title: The Signing of the Treaty of Waitangi
objective: Examine the development and impact of the British Empire.
description: The Treaty of Waitangi was signed between representatives of the British Crown and various Māori chiefs from the North Island of New Zealand. It marked the beginning of New Zealand becoming a part of the British Empire. The treaty aimed to protect Māori rights while asserting British sovereignty, and its interpretation and impact remain significant in New Zealand's history.

title: The Opening of the Stockton and Darlington Railway
objective: Analyze the social and economic changes during the Industrial Revolution.
description: The Stockton and Darlington Railway was the world's first public railway to use steam locomotives, marking a significant advancement in transportation. It facilitated the movement of goods and people, contributing to economic growth and the spread of industrialization.

title: D-Day: The Normandy Invasion
objective: Study the key events and outcomes of World War Two.
description: On June 6, 1944, Allied forces launched a massive invasion on the beaches of Normandy, France. Known as D-Day, this operation marked the beginning of the end for Nazi Germany, as it led to the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi occupation.

title: Kristallnacht
objective: Learn about the events and impact of the Holocaust.
description: Also known as the Night of Broken Glass, Kristallnacht was a pogrom against Jews carried out by the Nazi Party's paramilitary forces and civilians throughout Nazi Germany on 9–10 November 1938. Jewish homes, hospitals, and schools were ransacked, as the attackers demolished buildings with sledgehammers. Over 1,000 synagogues were burned and over 7,000 Jewish businesses were destroyed or damaged, marking a significant escalation in the Nazi campaign against Jews that would lead to the Holocaust.

title: Indian Independence Act
objective: Explore the process and impact of Indian independence from British rule.
description: The Indian Independence Act was passed by the British Parliament, leading to the end of British rule in India and the creation of two independent dominions, India and Pakistan, on August 15, 1947. This event marked a significant moment in world history, reshaping the political landscape of South Asia and ending nearly 200 years of British colonial rule.

title: The First Human Moon Landing by Apollo 11
The Signing of the Treaty of Tordesillas
The Invention of the Printing Press by Johannes Gutenberg
The Conquest of the Incan Empire by Francisco Pizarro
The English Reformation Begins
objective: Study the Renaissance and Reformation in Europe and their effects on Britain.
description: King Henry VIII's break from the Roman Catholic Church and the establishment of the Church of England, marking the beginning of the English Reformation. This event was significant as it led to religious, political, and social changes in Britain.

title: The Act of Supremacy
objective: Examine the causes and consequences of the English Reformation.
description: The Act of Supremacy was passed by the English Parliament, declaring King Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England. This marked a significant break from the Roman Catholic Church and was a pivotal event in the English Reformation.

title: Battle of Edgehill
objective: Analyze the causes and events of the civil wars throughout Britain.
description: The Battle of Edgehill was the first pitched battle of the English Civil War. It took place on October 23, 1642, between the Royalist forces led by King Charles I and the Parliamentarian forces. The battle ended inconclusively, setting the stage for continued conflict between the two sides.

title: Invention of the Spinning Jenny
objective: Understand Britain as the first industrial nation and its impact on society.
description: The Spinning Jenny, invented by James Hargreaves, revolutionized the production of yarn by allowing one worker to spin multiple spools at once, significantly increasing productivity in the textile industry. This invention is considered a key development in the Industrial Revolution, marking the shift from handmade to machine-made goods.

title: The Battle of Plassey
objective: Study the development of the British Empire and its global impact.
description: The Battle of Plassey was a decisive victory for the British East India Company over the Nawab of Bengal and his French allies. This marked the beginning of British control over India, which became a significant part of the British Empire.

title: Winston Churchill Becomes Prime Minister
objective: Study the events and impact of World War II, including the leadership of Winston Churchill.
description: In 1940, Winston Churchill became the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. His leadership during World War II was pivotal in rallying the British people and leading the country through its darkest hours. Churchill's speeches and determination were crucial in maintaining British morale and resistance against Nazi Germany.

title: Kristallnacht
objective: Understand the events and significance of the Holocaust.
description: Kristallnacht, or the Night of Broken Glass, occurred on November 9-10, 1938, and marked a significant escalation in the Nazi persecution of Jews. During these attacks, Jewish homes, businesses, and synagogues were destroyed across Germany and Austria, and thousands of Jews were arrested and sent to concentration camps.

title: Indian Independence Act
objective: Examine the process and impact of Indian independence and the end of the British Empire.
description: The Indian Independence Act was passed by the British Parliament, which led to the partition of India into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan. This marked the end of British colonial rule in India and had a profound impact on the region, leading to large-scale migration and communal violence.

title: Representation of the People Act
objective: Study the movement for women's suffrage and its achievements.
description: This significant event marked the first time women were granted the right to vote in parliamentary elections in the United Kingdom. The act enfranchised women over the age of 30 who met minimum property requirements, as well as all men over the age of 21. It was a major milestone in the women's suffrage movement.

title: The First Crusade Begins
objective: Explore the significance of the Crusades in Medieval history.
description: The First Crusade was launched in 1096, following a call to arms by Pope Urban II in 1095. The objective was to capture Jerusalem and the Holy Land from Muslim control. This event marked the beginning of a series of religious and military campaigns that had significant impacts on medieval Europe and the Middle East, influencing trade, politics, and cultural exchanges.

title: The Black Death Arrives in England
objective: Analyze the social and economic impact of the Black Death.
description: In 1348, the Black Death reached England, causing widespread panic and devastation. This pandemic led to the death of about a third of the population, significantly impacting the social and economic structures. The labor shortage caused by the high mortality rate led to increased wages for peasants and contributed to the decline of the feudal system.

title: Martin Luther's Ninety-Five Theses
objective: Explore the cultural and religious changes during the Renaissance and Reformation.
description: Martin Luther, a German monk, nailed his Ninety-Five Theses to the door of the Wittenberg Castle church, challenging the practices of the Catholic Church and sparking the Protestant Reformation.

title: Act of Supremacy
objective: Examine the religious transformations in England from Henry VIII to Mary I.
description: This act declared King Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England, marking the official break from the Roman Catholic Church and the beginning of the English Reformation.

title: The Glorious Revolution
objective: Understand the political changes during the Glorious Revolution.
description: The Glorious Revolution was a significant event in English history where King James II was overthrown and replaced by William III and Mary II. This revolution marked a shift in power from the monarchy to Parliament, leading to a constitutional monarchy and greater political stability in England.

title: Opening of the Stockton and Darlington Railway
objective: Analyze the impact of Britain as the first industrial nation.
description: The Stockton and Darlington Railway opened in 1825, marking the first time steam-powered locomotives were used to transport goods and passengers on a public railway. This event was significant as it showcased the potential of rail transport, which played a crucial role in the expansion of industry and trade during the Industrial Revolution in Britain.

title: The British Empire at its Height
objective: Study the development and impact of the British Empire.
description: In 1922, the British Empire was at its largest, covering approximately 13.71 million square miles and governing over 458 million people, about a quarter of the world's population at the time. This year marked the peak of British global influence, with territories on every inhabited continent.

title: D-Day: Allied Invasion of Normandy
objective: Understand the global impact and leadership during World War Two.
description: D-Day, on June 6, 1944, marked the largest seaborne invasion in history as Allied forces landed on the beaches of Normandy, France. This pivotal operation led to the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi control and showcased the leadership of figures like General Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: Indian Independence Act
objective: Examine the process and impact of Indian independence.
description: The Indian Independence Act was passed by the British Parliament on July 18, 1947, which led to the partition of British India into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan. The act marked the end of British rule in India and laid the foundation for the establishment of the sovereign states of India and Pakistan.

title: The First Crusade is Launched
objective: Explore the significance of the Crusades in Medieval Europe.
description: Pope Urban II called for the First Crusade in 1095, and by 1096, European knights and peasants began their journey to the Holy Land. This event marked the beginning of a series of religious wars aimed at capturing Jerusalem from Muslim control, significantly impacting Medieval Europe by fostering a sense of religious unity, increasing trade, and leading to cultural exchanges between Europe and the Middle East.

title: The Arrival of the Black Death in England
objective: Analyze the social and economic impact of the Black Death in Medieval Europe.
description: The Black Death, a devastating global epidemic of bubonic plague, arrived in England in 1348. It had profound social and economic impacts, drastically reducing the population, leading to labor shortages, and resulting in significant shifts in economic power and social structures. This event is crucial for understanding how the pandemic reshaped medieval European society.

title: Battle of Bosworth Field
objective: Investigate the causes and outcomes of the Wars of the Roses.
description: The Battle of Bosworth Field was the last significant battle of the Wars of the Roses, marking the end of the reign of Richard III and the rise of Henry Tudor, who became King Henry VII. This battle led to the establishment of the Tudor dynasty, which brought relative stability to England.

title: The Act of Supremacy
objective: Study the causes and effects of the English Reformation.
description: The Act of Supremacy was passed in 1534, declaring King Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England. This marked a significant break from the Roman Catholic Church and was a pivotal event in the English Reformation, leading to widespread religious, political, and social changes in England.

title: The Glorious Revolution
objective: Explore the events and significance of the Glorious Revolution.
description: The Glorious Revolution was the overthrow of King James II of England by a union of English Parliamentarians with the Dutch stadtholder William III of Orange-Nassau (William of Orange). The revolution led to the ascension of William III and Mary II to the English throne and marked the beginning of a constitutional monarchy, significantly limiting the powers of the monarchy and laying the foundation for the modern parliamentary democracy.

title: The Battle of Plassey
objective: Examine the development and impact of the British Empire.
description: The Battle of Plassey was a decisive victory by the British East India Company over the Nawab of Bengal and his French allies. This marked the beginning of British colonial dominance in India, significantly expanding the British Empire's influence in the region.

title: The Opening of the Liverpool and Manchester Railway
objective: Analyze the social and economic changes during the Industrial Revolution.
description: The Liverpool and Manchester Railway, the first inter-city railway in the world, opened in 1830. It marked a significant advancement in transportation during the Industrial Revolution, facilitating the rapid movement of goods and people, and contributing to economic growth and urbanization.

title: D-Day (Operation Overlord)
objective: Study the key events and outcomes of World War Two.
description: The Allied invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944, marked a significant turning point in World War Two. Known as D-Day, this operation involved the largest seaborne invasion in history and led to the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi control.

title: Kristallnacht (The Night of Broken Glass)
objective: Learn about the events and impact of the Holocaust.
description: A pogrom against Jews carried out by SA paramilitary forces and civilians throughout Nazi Germany on 9-10 November 1938. Jewish homes, businesses, and synagogues were destroyed, marking a significant escalation in Nazi anti-Jewish policy.

title: Indian Independence Act
objective: Explore the process and impact of Indian independence from British rule.
description: The Indian Independence Act was passed by the British Parliament, leading to the partition of India and the creation of two independent dominions, India and Pakistan. This marked the end of British rule in India and was a significant moment in the decolonization of the British Empire.

title: Battle of Hastings
description: The Battle of Hastings took place in 1066 and was a pivotal event in the Norman Conquest of England. It saw the defeat of King Harold II by William the Conqueror, leading to Norman control over England.
objective: Understand the events and impact of the Norman Conquest on Britain.

title: The Signing of the Magna Carta
description: The Magna Carta was signed by King John of England at Runnymede. It was a crucial document that limited the power of the monarchy and laid the foundation for modern democracy, influencing the relationship between the church, state, and society.
objective: Explore the development of Church, state, and society in Medieval Britain from 1066-1509.

title: Martin Luther's Ninety-Five Theses
description: Martin Luther, a German monk, nailed his Ninety-Five Theses to the door of the Wittenberg Castle church, challenging the practices of the Catholic Church and sparking the Protestant Reformation. This event had significant religious, cultural, and political effects across Europe, including Britain, leading to the establishment of Protestantism.
objective: Study the Renaissance and Reformation in Europe and their effects on Britain.

title: Henry VIII's Break with Rome
description: King Henry VIII, seeking to annul his marriage to Catherine of Aragon, breaks away from the Roman Catholic Church and establishes the Church of England, marking the beginning of the English Reformation.
objective: Examine the causes and consequences of the English Reformation.

title: Battle of Naseby
description: The Battle of Naseby was a decisive engagement of the English Civil War. Fought on 14 June 1645, it marked a turning point in the conflict, favoring the Parliamentarians led by Sir Thomas Fairfax and Oliver Cromwell against the Royalist forces of King Charles I.
objective: Analyze the causes and events of the civil wars throughout Britain.

title: The Invention of the Spinning Jenny
description: James Hargreaves invented the Spinning Jenny, a multi-spindle spinning frame, which revolutionized the textile industry by allowing workers to produce multiple spools of thread simultaneously.
objective: Understand Britain as the first industrial nation and its impact on society.

title: The First Fleet Arrives in Australia
description: The First Fleet, a group of 11 ships carrying convicts, marines, and officers from Britain, arrived at Port Jackson, New South Wales. This marked the beginning of British colonization in Australia and was a significant step in the expansion of the British Empire.
objective: Study the development of the British Empire and its global impact.

title: Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand
description: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary on June 28, 1914, in Sarajevo was a pivotal event that led to the outbreak of World War I. It set off a chain reaction of alliances and mobilizations that escalated into a global conflict.
objective: Explore the causes, events, and consequences of World War I.

title: Dunkirk Evacuation
description: The Dunkirk Evacuation, also known as Operation Dynamo, was the evacuation of Allied soldiers from the beaches and harbour of Dunkirk, France, between May 26 and June 4, 1940. This operation was crucial in saving over 300,000 British and Allied troops who were surrounded by German forces.
objective: Study the events and impact of World War II, including the leadership of Winston Churchill.

title: Kristallnacht (The Night of Broken Glass)
description: A coordinated attack on Jewish people and their properties in Nazi Germany, marking a significant escalation in the Nazi campaign against Jews.
objective: Understand the events and significance of the Holocaust.

title: Indian Independence Act
description: The Indian Independence Act was passed by the British Parliament, leading to the partition of British India into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan. This marked the end of British rule in India and the beginning of self-governance for both nations.
objective: Examine the process and impact of Indian independence and the end of the British Empire.

title: Representation of the People Act
description: The Representation of the People Act 1918 was a pivotal piece of legislation in the United Kingdom that granted the right to vote to women over the age of 30 who met certain property qualifications. This act significantly expanded the electorate and marked a major achievement in the women's suffrage movement.
objective: Study the movement for women's suffrage and its achievements.

title: The First Crusade Begins
description: The First Crusade was launched in 1096 after Pope Urban II's call to help the Byzantine Empire reclaim land from Muslim control. This marked the beginning of a series of religious wars aimed at capturing the Holy Land, significantly impacting both Europe and the Middle East.
objective: Explore the significance of the Crusades in Medieval history.

title: Signing of the Magna Carta
description: The Magna Carta was signed by King John of England at Runnymede, establishing the principle that the king and his government were not above the law. It laid the foundation for the development of Parliament and constitutional law.
objective: Examine the emergence of Parliament and its historical significance.

title: The Arrival of the Black Death in England
description: The Black Death arrived in England in 1348, brought by ships docking at the port of Melcombe Regis in Dorset. This event marked the beginning of the epidemic in England, leading to widespread social and economic upheaval, as the plague decimated the population, causing labor shortages and changes in the feudal system.
objective: Analyze the social and economic impact of the Black Death.

title: Battle of Agincourt
description: The Battle of Agincourt was a major English victory in the Hundred Years War. King Henry V's forces defeated a numerically superior French army, showcasing the effectiveness of the English longbow and tactics.
objective: Understand the causes and effects of the Hundred Years War.

title: Act of Supremacy
description: The Act of Supremacy was passed by the English Parliament, declaring King Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England, marking a significant break from the Roman Catholic Church.
objective: Examine the religious transformations in England from Henry VIII to Mary I.

title: The Glorious Revolution
description: The Glorious Revolution was a significant event in British history when King James II was overthrown and replaced by William III and Mary II. This revolution marked a shift in power from the monarchy to Parliament, leading to the establishment of a constitutional monarchy in England.
objective: Understand the political changes during the Glorious Revolution.

title: The Opening of the Stockton and Darlington Railway
description: The Stockton and Darlington Railway was the world's first public railway to use steam locomotives. Its opening marked a significant development in the transportation of goods and people, which was crucial for the industrialization of Britain and the expansion of industries like coal and textiles.
objective: Analyze the impact of Britain as the first industrial nation.

title: The Battle of Plassey
description: The Battle of Plassey was a decisive victory of the British East India Company over the Nawab of Bengal and his French allies. This battle marked the beginning of British control over India and was a significant event in the expansion of the British Empire.
objective: Study the development and impact of the British Empire.

title: D-Day Landings
description: On June 6, 1944, Allied forces launched the largest seaborne invasion in history, known as D-Day. This marked the beginning of the liberation of German-occupied France and later Western Europe, showcasing the global impact of World War Two and the strategic leadership of Allied commanders.
objective: Understand the global impact and leadership during World War Two.

title: Indian Independence and Partition
description: In 1947, India gained independence from British rule. This significant event also led to the partition of India, resulting in the creation of two separate nations, India and Pakistan. The partition caused massive displacement and violence as millions of people migrated across the new borders, impacting the lives of countless individuals and shaping the region's future.
objective: Examine the process and impact of Indian independence.

title: The Black Death Reaches England
description: In 1348, the Black Death, a devastating pandemic, arrived in England. This event marked the beginning of a catastrophic period that would significantly alter the social and economic landscape of Medieval Europe. The rapid spread of the disease led to a massive decline in population, which in turn caused labor shortages and shifts in feudal structures. The scarcity of workers empowered peasants to demand higher wages and better working conditions, contributing to the eventual decline of the feudal system.
objective: Analyze the social and economic impact of the Black Death in Medieval Europe.

title: Battle of Bosworth Field
description: The Battle of Bosworth Field was the last significant battle of the Wars of the Roses, where Richard III was defeated by Henry Tudor. This victory led to Henry Tudor becoming King Henry VII, marking the end of the Plantagenet dynasty and the beginning of the Tudor dynasty.
objective: Investigate the causes and outcomes of the Wars of the Roses.

title: The Act of Supremacy
description: The Act of Supremacy was passed by the English Parliament, declaring King Henry VIII as the Supreme Head of the Church of England. This marked a significant break from the Roman Catholic Church and was a major event in the English Reformation.
objective: Study the causes and effects of the English Reformation.

title: The Signing of the Treaty of Paris
description: The Treaty of Paris was signed in 1763, marking the end of the Seven Years' War. This treaty significantly expanded the British Empire, as Britain gained control over Canada, Florida, and various territories in India and the Caribbean. This expansion marked a major increase in British global influence and laid the groundwork for future imperial growth.
objective: Examine the development and impact of the British Empire.

title: Introduction of the Factory System
description: In 1769, Richard Arkwright patented the water frame, a significant development in the textile industry that led to the establishment of factories. This marked the transition from hand production methods to machines, significantly altering social and economic structures by increasing production capacity and creating a new labor class.
objective: Analyze the social and economic changes during the Industrial Revolution.

title: Kristallnacht
description: Kristallnacht, or the Night of Broken Glass, was a pogrom against Jews carried out by the Nazi regime throughout Nazi Germany on 9–10 November 1938. Jewish homes, businesses, and synagogues were attacked and destroyed, marking a significant escalation in Nazi anti-Jewish policy.
objective: Learn about the events and impact of the Holocaust.

title: The Discovery of Lascaux Cave Paintings
description: The Lascaux Caves in France, discovered in 1940, contain some of the most famous examples of Upper Paleolithic art. These paintings, estimated to be around 17,000 years old, provide insight into the life and environment of prehistoric humans through depictions of large animals that once roamed the region.
objective: Understand the life and environment of prehistoric humans.

title: Construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza
description: The Great Pyramid of Giza, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, was constructed during the reign of Pharaoh Khufu. This monumental achievement demonstrates the advanced engineering and architectural skills of ancient Egyptian civilization.
objective: Explore the characteristics and contributions of ancient civilizations such as Egypt, Mesopotamia, and the Indus Valley.

title: Invention of Democracy in Athens
description: In 508 BCE, Athens established one of the first known democracies, where citizens could participate in decision-making processes. This political advancement laid the foundation for democratic systems in the modern world.
objective: Learn about the political, cultural, and technological advancements of Greek and Roman societies.

title: The Coronation of Charlemagne as Emperor
description: On Christmas Day in the year 800, Charlemagne was crowned Emperor by Pope Leo III in Rome. This event marked the revival of the Roman Empire in the West and established the Carolingian Empire, which played a crucial role in shaping the social, political, and cultural landscape of the Middle Ages in Europe.
objective: Examine the social structures, key events, and cultural developments of the Middle Ages.

title: Publication of 'De revolutionibus orbium coelestium'
description: Nicolaus Copernicus published his groundbreaking work 'De revolutionibus orbium coelestium' (On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres), which proposed the heliocentric model of the universe, challenging the geocentric model and significantly advancing scientific thought during the Renaissance.
objective: Understand the major changes in art, science, and thought during the Renaissance period.

title: Christopher Columbus Discovers the Americas
description: In 1492, Christopher Columbus, an Italian explorer sailing under the Spanish flag, reached the Americas. This event marked the beginning of European exploration and colonization of the American continents. Columbus's voyage was motivated by the desire to find new trade routes to Asia, but it ultimately led to the widespread exchange of goods, cultures, and ideas between the Old and New Worlds, known as the Columbian Exchange.
objective: Explore the motivations and impacts of European exploration and colonization.

title: Invention of the Steam Engine
description: James Watt patented an improved steam engine design, which became a key driver of the Industrial Revolution, powering factories, trains, and ships, and transforming industries and transportation.
objective: Analyze the technological advancements and societal changes during the Industrial Revolution.

title: Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand
description: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria on June 28, 1914, in Sarajevo is often cited as the immediate spark that led to the outbreak of World War I. This event set off a chain of alliances and conflicts that escalated into a full-scale war.
objective: Study the causes, major events, and consequences of World War I and World War II.

title: Fall of the Berlin Wall
description: The Berlin Wall, which had divided East and West Berlin since 1961, was brought down in 1989. This event symbolized the end of the Cold War and led to the reunification of Germany.
objective: Discuss the key events and developments in the world from the late 20th century to the present.

title: Lascaux Cave Paintings
description: The Lascaux Caves in southwestern France are home to some of the most famous examples of prehistoric cave paintings. These artworks, created by early humans, depict large animals and human figures, providing insight into the life and environment of prehistoric humans.
objective: Understand the life and environment of prehistoric humans.

title: Unification of Upper and Lower Egypt
description: The unification of Upper and Lower Egypt under the rule of the first Pharaoh, Narmer, marked the beginning of the ancient Egyptian civilization. This event laid the foundation for a centralized state that would last for thousands of years, leading to remarkable achievements in architecture, writing, and governance.
objective: Explore the development and characteristics of ancient civilizations such as Egypt, Mesopotamia, and the Indus Valley.

title: Battle of Actium
description: The Battle of Actium was a decisive confrontation that took place in 31 BC, marking the end of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire. It was fought between the forces of Octavian and the combined forces of Mark Antony and Cleopatra. Octavian's victory led to his sole control of Rome and the beginning of the Pax Romana.
objective: Study the rise and fall of the Greek and Roman Empires and their influence on modern society.

title: Coronation of Charlemagne
description: Charlemagne was crowned Emperor of the Romans by Pope Leo III on December 25, 800, marking the revival of the Roman Empire in the West and laying the foundations for the Holy Roman Empire.
objective: Examine the key events and societal changes during the Middle Ages in Europe.

title: Leonardo da Vinci Paints the Mona Lisa
description: Leonardo da Vinci began painting the Mona Lisa, one of the most famous works of art from the Renaissance period, showcasing advancements in artistic techniques and human expression.
objective: Understand the cultural, artistic, and scientific advancements during the Renaissance period.

title: Storming of the Bastille
description: On July 14, 1789, revolutionaries stormed the Bastille prison in Paris, a symbol of the monarchy's tyranny. This event marked the beginning of the French Revolution and is celebrated annually as Bastille Day, symbolizing the end of absolute monarchy and the birth of the people's sovereignty.
objective: Analyze the causes, events, and outcomes of the French Revolution.

title: Invention of the Spinning Jenny
description: The Spinning Jenny, invented by James Hargreaves, revolutionized the textile industry by allowing a single worker to spin multiple spools of thread at the same time, significantly increasing productivity and reducing the cost of cloth.
objective: Explore the technological and societal changes brought about by the Industrial Revolution.

title: The Code of Hammurabi
description: The Code of Hammurabi, one of the earliest and most complete written legal codes, was proclaimed by the Babylonian king Hammurabi. It provided a set of rules for commercial interactions and set fines and punishments to meet the requirements of justice.
objective: Explore the development and characteristics of ancient civilizations.

title: Coronation of Charlemagne as Emperor
description: On December 25, 800, Charlemagne was crowned Emperor of the Romans by Pope Leo III. This event marked the revival of the Roman Empire in the West and was significant for the development of the Holy Roman Empire, influencing the political and cultural landscape of medieval Europe.
objective: Understand the societal and cultural changes during the Middle Ages.

title: The Invention of the Printing Press by Johannes Gutenberg
description: Johannes Gutenberg's invention of the movable-type printing press in 1440 revolutionized the way information was disseminated, leading to the spread of knowledge and ideas across Europe, which played a crucial role in the cultural and intellectual movement of the Renaissance.
objective: Examine the key figures and innovations of the Renaissance period.

title: Berlin Conference and the Partition of Africa (1884–85)
objective: Understand the impact of European colonization on Africa and the geopolitical decisions made at the Berlin Conference.

title: Construction of the Suez Canal (1869)
objective: Learn about the significance of the Suez Canal in global trade and its geopolitical implications.

title: Establishment of Liberia as an independent republic (1847)
objective: Explore the history of Liberia and its establishment as a nation founded by freed American slaves.

title: British annexation of the Zulu Kingdom (1879)
objective: Understand the causes and consequences of the British annexation of the Zulu Kingdom.

title: Kwame Nkrumah leads Ghana to independence (1957)
objective: Learn about Ghana's path to independence and the role of Kwame Nkrumah in the decolonization movement.

title: Rwandan Genocide (1994)
objective: Examine the causes and aftermath of the Rwandan Genocide and its impact on international human rights.

title: Founding of the African Union (2002)
objective: Understand the objectives and challenges of the African Union in promoting unity and development in Africa.

title: Ethiopia’s Grand Renaissance Dam dispute (2010s)
objective: Analyze the geopolitical tensions surrounding the construction of the Grand Renaissance Dam.

title: Rise of mobile banking in Kenya (M-Pesa)
objective: Explore the impact of M-Pesa on financial inclusion and economic development in Kenya.

title: Nigerian End SARS protests (2020)
objective: Understand the causes and significance of the End SARS protests in Nigeria.

title: South Africa’s electricity crisis (Eskom, 2000s–2020s)
objective: Examine the challenges and implications of South Africa's electricity crisis.

title: Rise of the Olmec Civilization (c. 1200 BCE)
objective: Learn about the Olmec civilization and its contributions to Mesoamerican culture.

title: Teotihuacan established in central Mexico (c. 100 BCE)
objective: Explore the rise and significance of Teotihuacan in Mesoamerican history.

title: Maya City of Tikal reaches its peak (200 CE)
objective: Understand the cultural and political significance of Tikal during the height of the Maya civilization.

title: Nazca Lines created in Peru (c. 500 BCE–500 CE)
objective: Discover the mysteries and significance of the Nazca Lines in Peru.

title: Chavín culture flourishes in the Andes (900–200 BCE)
objective: Learn about the Chavín culture and its influence on Andean civilizations.

title: Mayan decline in southern lowlands (c. 900)
objective: Examine the factors leading to the decline of the Maya civilization in the southern lowlands.

title: Rise of the Mississippian Culture (800–1600)
objective: Understand the development and characteristics of the Mississippian culture in North America.

title: Tairona civilization flourishes in northern Colombia
objective: Explore the Tairona civilization and its contributions to pre-Columbian South America.

title: Founding of New Amsterdam (later New York) (1624)
objective: Learn about the establishment of New Amsterdam and its transformation into New York City.

title: Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire (1532)
objective: Understand the events and consequences of the Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire.

title: Jesuit missions in Paraguay (1600s)
objective: Explore the role and impact of Jesuit missions in the cultural and social landscape of Paraguay.

title: Persian Empire under Darius the Great (522–486 BCE)
objective: Learn about the achievements and administration of the Persian Empire under Darius the Great.

title: Qin Dynasty unifies China (221 BCE)
objective: Understand the significance of the unification of China under the Qin Dynasty.

title: Invention of paper in Han China (c. 100 BCE)
objective: Explore the invention of paper in Han China and its impact on communication and record-keeping.

title: Fall of the Ming Dynasty (1644)
objective: Examine the factors leading to the fall of the Ming Dynasty and the rise of the Qing Dynasty.

title: Mughal Empire under Akbar the Great (1556–1605)
objective: Learn about the rule of Akbar the Great and the cultural and administrative achievements of the Mughal Empire.

title: Tokugawa shogunate begins in Japan (1603)
objective: Understand the establishment and impact of the Tokugawa shogunate on Japanese society.

title: China’s Belt and Road Initiative launches (2013)
objective: Analyze the goals and global impact of China's Belt and Road Initiative.

title: Beijing Olympics (2008)
objective: Explore the significance of the 2008 Beijing Olympics in showcasing China's global presence.

title: Indian Mars Orbiter Mission (2013)
objective: Learn about India's Mars Orbiter Mission and its achievements in space exploration.

title: World's first telegraph line installed (1837)
objective: Understand the development and impact of the telegraph on global communication.

title: First World Expo in London (1851)
objective: Explore the significance of the first World Expo in promoting global innovation and cultural exchange.

title: Standardization of time zones (1884)
objective: Learn about the reasons and process behind the standardization of time zones.

title: International Red Cross founded (1863)
objective: Understand the founding principles and humanitarian mission of the International Red Cross.

title: Birth of international labor movements (mid-1800s)
objective: Explore the origins and goals of international labor movements in the 19th century.

title: Fall of the Berlin Wall (1989)
objective: Learn about the events leading to the fall of the Berlin Wall and its impact on the Cold War.

title: Formation of NATO (1949)
objective: Understand the reasons behind the formation of NATO and its role during the Cold War.

title: Moon Landing by Apollo 11 (1969)
objective: Explore the significance of the Apollo 11 mission and its impact on space exploration.

title: Creation of the United Nations (1945)
objective: Learn about the founding of the United Nations and its objectives in promoting global peace.

title: Spanish Flu pandemic (1918–1919)
objective: Understand the impact of the Spanish Flu pandemic on global health and society.

title: Arab Spring begins (2010)
objective: Analyze the causes and effects of the Arab Spring on the Middle East and North Africa.

title: Wikileaks releases classified U.S. documents (2010)
objective: Explore the implications of the Wikileaks releases on transparency and international relations.

title: Global Financial Crisis (2008)
objective: Understand the causes and global impact of the 2008 financial crisis.

title: COVID-19 Pandemic declared (2020)
objective: Learn about the global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on health, society, and economies.

title: Paris Climate Agreement signed (2015)
objective: Explore the goals and significance of the Paris Climate Agreement in addressing climate change.
